topic: Fixed Income Bond Valuation_ Prices and Yields

questions.title: Fixed Income Bond Valuation_ Prices and Yields
questions.question: A non-callable, fixed-coupon bond has a price of 106.0625 and a YTM of 2.8%. If the YTM were to increase instantaneously by 80 bps, the price of the bond would decrease by 11%. If the YTM were to decrease instantaneously by 80 bps, the price of the bond would increase by:
questions.explanation: Solution C is correct. The absolute amount of the price increase would be more than the absolute amount of the price decrease for the same absolute change in YTM because of the convex relationship between bond price and yield. A is incorrect because of the positive convex relationship between bond price and yield. For a given level of yield change, the price rise for that given amount of yield decrease will be larger than the price decline for that amount of yield increase. B is incorrect because the relationship between bond price and yield is not linear.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

C is correct. The absolute amount of the price increase would be more than the absolute amount of the price decrease for the same absolute change in YTM because of the convex relationship between bond price and yield.

A is incorrect because of the positive convex relationship between bond price and yield. For a given level of yield change, the price rise for that given amount of yield decrease will be larger than the price decline for that amount of yield increase.

B is incorrect because the relationship between bond price and yield is not linear.

questions.title: Fixed Income Bond Valuation_ Prices and Yields
questions.question:
The market value of an 18-year zero-coupon bond with a maturity value of $1,000 discounted at a 12% annual interest rate with semi-annual compounding is closest to:

  1. $122.74.
  2. $130.04.
  3. $192.86.
questions.explanation: Solution Correct. The value of a zero-coupon bond is Face¬†value ( 1 + ùëü ) ùëÅ Face¬†value ( 1 + r ) N where r is the market discount rate per period, and N is the number of evenly spaced periods to maturity. The value of the zero-coupon bond is $ 1 , 000 ( 1 + 0.12 / 2 ) 18 √ó 2 = $ 122.74 $ 1 , 000 ( 1 + 0.12 / 2 ) 18 √ó 2 = $ 122.74 Incorrect because it uses the annual discount rate and the maturity in years rather than adjusting the discount rate and maturity for semi-annual periods. Incorrect because it uses the semi-annual coupons times the number of years divided by 1.12. Fixed-Income Bond Valuation: Prices and Yields calculate a bond‚Äôs price given a yield-to-maturity on or between coupon dates
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Correct. The value of a zero-coupon bond is

    Face¬†value(1+ùëü)ùëÅFace¬†value(1+r)N

    where r is the market discount rate per period, and N is the number of evenly spaced periods to maturity. The value of the zero-coupon bond is

    $1,000(1+0.12/2)18√ó2=$122.74$1,000(1+0.12/2)18√ó2=$122.74

  2. Incorrect because it uses the annual discount rate and the maturity in years rather than adjusting the discount rate and maturity for semi-annual periods.

  3. Incorrect because it uses the semi-annual coupons times the number of years divided by 1.12.

Fixed-Income Bond Valuation: Prices and Yields

questions.title: Fixed Income Bond Valuation_ Prices and Yields
questions.question:
An investor sells a bond at the quoted price of $98.00. In addition, she receives accrued interest of $4.40. The flat price of the bond is equal to the:

  1. par value plus accrued interest.
  2. accrued interest plus the agreed-on bond price.
  3. agreed-on bond price excluding accrued interest.
questions.explanation: Solution Incorrect because flat price is the agreed-upon bond price excluding accrued interest. Incorrect because flat price excludes accrued interest. Correct. The agreed-on bond price excluding accrued interest is referred to as the flat price. Fixed-Income Bond Valuation: Prices and Yields calculate a bond‚Äôs price given a yield-to-maturity on or between coupon dates
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Incorrect because flat price is the agreed-upon bond price excluding accrued interest.

  2. Incorrect because flat price excludes accrued interest.

  3. Correct. The agreed-on bond price excluding accrued interest is referred to as the flat price.

Fixed-Income Bond Valuation: Prices and Yields

  • calculate a bond‚Äôs price given a yield-to-maturity on or between coupon dates

questions.title: Fixed Income Bond Valuation_ Prices and Yields
questions.question: Exceptions to the maturity effect exist for bonds that have:

choices.A: long maturities, make small coupon payments, and trade at a discount.
choices.B: short maturities, have high coupon rates, and trade at a discount.
choices.C: long maturities, have high coupon rates, and trade at a premium.

questions.explanation: Solution A is correct. Exceptions to the maturity effect are rare and occur only for low-coupon (but not zero-coupon) long-term bonds trading at a discount. B is incorrect because the maturity effect holds for bonds that have short maturities and high coupons. C is incorrect because the maturity effect always holds on bonds priced at a premium above par value.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

A is correct. Exceptions to the maturity effect are rare and occur only for low-coupon (but not zero-coupon) long-term bonds trading at a discount.

B is incorrect because the maturity effect holds for bonds that have short maturities and high coupons.

C is incorrect because the maturity effect always holds on bonds priced at a premium above par value.

questions.title: Fixed Income Bond Valuation_ Prices and Yields
questions.question: With a constant market discount rate, as a non-callable, fixed-coupon bond approaches maturity:

choices.A: the price‚Äìyield relationship will become more convex.
choices.B: a low-coupon bond trading at a discount will increase in price.
choices.C: a high-coupon bond trading at a premium will increase in price.

questions.explanation: Solution B is correct. Any bond trading at a discount will increase in price because of the pull-to-par effect. A is incorrect because the price‚Äìyield relationship generally becomes less convex as a bond approaches maturity. C is incorrect because a high-coupon bond trading at a premium will decrease in price as it approaches maturity.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

B is correct. Any bond trading at a discount will increase in price because of the pull-to-par effect.

A is incorrect because the price‚Äìyield relationship generally becomes less convex as a bond approaches maturity.

C is incorrect because a high-coupon bond trading at a premium will decrease in price as it approaches maturity.

questions.title: Fixed Income Bond Valuation_ Prices and Yields
questions.question:
Bonds are quoted using the:

  1. full price and settled using the flat price.
  2. flat price and settled using the full price.
  3. dirty price and settled using the invoice price.
questions.explanation: Solution Incorrect because the flat price usually is quoted by bond dealers. If a trade takes place, the accrued interest is added to the flat price to obtain the full price paid by the buyer and received by the seller on the settlement date. Correct because the flat price usually is quoted by bond dealers. If a trade takes place, the accrued interest is added to the flat price to obtain the full price paid by the buyer and received by the seller on the settlement date. Incorrect because the flat price usually is quoted by bond dealers. If a trade takes place, the accrued interest is added to the flat price to obtain the full price paid by the buyer and received by the seller on the settlement date and the full price also is called the invoice or 'dirty' price. Fixed-Income Bond Valuation: Prices and Yields calculate a bond‚Äôs price given a yield-to-maturity on or between coupon dates
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Incorrect because the flat price usually is quoted by bond dealers. If a trade takes place, the accrued interest is added to the flat price to obtain the full price paid by the buyer and received by the seller on the settlement date.

  2. Correct because the flat price usually is quoted by bond dealers. If a trade takes place, the accrued interest is added to the flat price to obtain the full price paid by the buyer and received by the seller on the settlement date.

  3. Incorrect because the flat price usually is quoted by bond dealers. If a trade takes place, the accrued interest is added to the flat price to obtain the full price paid by the buyer and received by the seller on the settlement date and the full price also is called the invoice or 'dirty' price.

Fixed-Income Bond Valuation: Prices and Yields

  • calculate a bond‚Äôs price given a yield-to-maturity on or between coupon dates

questions.title: Fixed Income Bond Valuation_ Prices and Yields
questions.question:
A credit analyst is least likely to use matrix pricing to estimate the required yield and price of a(n):

  1. newly underwritten bond.
  2. actively traded speculative grade bond.
  3. inactively traded investment grade bond.
questions.explanation: Solution Incorrect because matrix pricing is most suited to pricing newly underwritten bonds. Correct. Matrix pricing is most suited to pricing inactively traded bonds and newly underwritten bonds. A credit analyst is least likely to use matrix pricing to price an actively traded bond. Incorrect because matrix pricing is most suited to pricing inactively traded bonds. Fixed-Income Bond Valuation: Prices and Yields describe matrix pricing
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Incorrect because matrix pricing is most suited to pricing newly underwritten bonds.

  2. Correct. Matrix pricing is most suited to pricing inactively traded bonds and newly underwritten bonds. A credit analyst is least likely to use matrix pricing to price an actively traded bond.

  3. Incorrect because matrix pricing is most suited to pricing inactively traded bonds.

Fixed-Income Bond Valuation: Prices and Yields

  • describe matrix pricing

questions.title: Fixed Income Bond Valuation_ Prices and Yields
questions.question:
A fixed-income analyst is pricing a bond using the following equation.

ùëÉùëâ=3(1+0.0275)1+3(1+0.0275)2+....+103(1+0.0275)40PV=3(1+0.0275)1+3(1+0.0275)2+....+103(1+0.0275)40

The bond‚Äôs price, relative to par, is most likely:
questions.explanation: Solution A is correct. The bond‚Äôs periodic coupon rate exceeds the periodic market discount rate, or its coupon rate is ‚Äúexcessive‚Äù relative to the market. Therefore, the bond will trade at a premium to par. B is incorrect. For the bond to trade at par, the coupon rate and market discount rate (yield-to-maturity) must be equal. C is incorrect. For the bond to trade at a discount, the yield-to-maturity would have to be higher than the coupon rate.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

A is correct. The bond‚Äôs periodic coupon rate exceeds the periodic market discount rate, or its coupon rate is ‚Äúexcessive‚Äù relative to the market. Therefore, the bond will trade at a premium to par.

B is incorrect. For the bond to trade at par, the coupon rate and market discount rate (yield-to-maturity) must be equal.

C is incorrect. For the bond to trade at a discount, the yield-to-maturity would have to be higher than the coupon rate.

questions.title: Fixed Income Bond Valuation_ Prices and Yields
questions.question: A four-year, 2.0% semiannual coupon bond that pays coupons semiannually is trading at a price of 102.581. The bond‚Äôs annualized yield-to-maturity is closest to:
questions.explanation: Solution B is correct. Two approaches to calculating the yield-to-maturity are calculating an IRR or using the YIELD function in Microsoft Excel or Google Sheets. The periodic IRR is annualized by multiplying by two. Period Cash Flow YIELD Function 0 ‚Äì102.581 Settlement date 1/1/2000 1 1 Maturity date 1/1/2004 2 1 Coupon 0.02 3 1 Price 102.581 4 1 Redemption 100 5 1 Coupon frequency 2 6 1 Yield 1.34% 7 1 8 101 Periodic IRR 0.67% Annualized IRR 1.34% A is incorrect because 0.67% is the periodic, not annualized, yield-to-maturity. C is incorrect. Note that this choice can be eliminated because the bond is trading at a premium; thus its yield-to-maturity is lower than its coupon rate of 2.0%. Please refer to the candidate learning ecosystem online for a spreadsheet of these calculations in the downloaded¬†Microsoft Excel workbook .
questions.solution_html:
Solution

B is correct. Two approaches to calculating the yield-to-maturity are calculating an IRR or using the YIELD function in Microsoft Excel or Google Sheets. The periodic IRR is annualized by multiplying by two.

Period Cash Flow YIELD Function
0 ‚Äì102.581 Settlement date 1/1/2000
1 1 Maturity date 1/1/2004
2 1 Coupon 0.02
3 1 Price 102.581
4 1 Redemption 100
5 1 Coupon frequency 2
6 1 Yield 1.34%
7 1
8 101
Periodic IRR 0.67%
Annualized IRR 1.34%

A is incorrect because 0.67% is the periodic, not annualized, yield-to-maturity.

C is incorrect. Note that this choice can be eliminated because the bond is trading at a premium; thus its yield-to-maturity is lower than its coupon rate of 2.0%.

Please refer to the candidate learning ecosystem online for a spreadsheet of these calculations in the¬†downloaded¬†Microsoft Excel workbook.

questions.title: Fixed Income Bond Valuation_ Prices and Yields
questions.question:
Consider two bonds that are identical except for their coupon rates. The bond that will have the highest interest rate risk most likely has the:

  1. lowest coupon rate.
  2. coupon rate closest to its market yield.
  3. highest coupon rate.
questions.explanation: Solution Correct. A lower coupon rate means that more of the bond‚Äôs value comes from repayment of face value, which occurs at the end of the bond‚Äôs life. Incorrect because the relationship between the coupon rate and the yield of a bond affect the relationship between the price and face value of the bond, not its interest rate risk. Incorrect because a higher coupon rate means that more of the bond‚Äôs value comes from coupon payments, which occur earlier in a bond‚Äôs life. Fixed-Income Bond Valuation: Prices and Yields identify the relationships among a bond‚Äôs price, coupon rate, maturity, and yield-to-maturity
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Correct. A lower coupon rate means that more of the bond‚Äôs value comes from repayment of face value, which occurs at the end of the bond‚Äôs life.

  2. Incorrect because the relationship between the coupon rate and the yield of a bond affect the relationship between the price and face value of the bond, not its interest rate risk.

  3. Incorrect because a higher coupon rate means that more of the bond‚Äôs value comes from coupon payments, which occur earlier in a bond‚Äôs life.

Fixed-Income Bond Valuation: Prices and Yields

  • identify the relationships among a bond‚Äôs price, coupon rate, maturity, and yield-to-maturity

questions.title: Fixed Income Bond Valuation_ Prices and Yields
questions.question: A bond is traded in between its coupon payment dates. Which of the following is true?

choices.A: The buyer must pay the full price plus the accrued interest.
choices.B: The bond‚Äôs quoted price is greater than its flat price.
choices.C: Accrued interest is not included in the flat price.

questions.explanation: Solution C is correct. The flat price, quoted by bond dealers, is the full price less accrued interest. Accrued interest is not included in the flat price. A is incorrect. The buyer must pay the full price, which already includes accrued interest. B is incorrect. The flat price is the quoted price.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

C is correct. The flat price, quoted by bond dealers, is the full price less accrued interest. Accrued interest is not included in the flat price.

A is incorrect. The buyer must pay the full price, which already includes accrued interest.

B is incorrect. The flat price is the quoted price.

questions.title: Fixed Income Bond Valuation_ Prices and Yields
questions.question:
An investor purchases the bonds of JLD Corp., which pay an annual coupon of 10% and mature in 10 years, at an annual yield to maturity of 12%. The bonds will most likely be selling at:

  1. par.
  2. a premium.
  3. a discount.
questions.explanation: Solution Incorrect because the bonds will sell at par if the coupon rate on the bonds is equal to the yield to maturity. Incorrect because the bonds will sell at a premium if the coupon rate on the bonds is higher than the yield to maturity. Correct. The coupon rate on the bonds is lower than the yield to maturity, implying that the bonds should be selling at a price lower than their par value‚Äîthat is, at a discount. Fixed-Income Bond Valuation: Prices and Yields identify the relationships among a bond‚Äôs price, coupon rate, maturity, and yield-to-maturity
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Incorrect because the bonds will sell at par if the coupon rate on the bonds is equal to the yield to maturity.

  2. Incorrect because the bonds will sell at a premium if the coupon rate on the bonds is higher than the yield to maturity.

  3. Correct. The coupon rate on the bonds is lower than the yield to maturity, implying that the bonds should be selling at a price lower than their par value‚Äîthat is, at a discount.

Fixed-Income Bond Valuation: Prices and Yields

  • identify the relationships among a bond‚Äôs price, coupon rate, maturity, and yield-to-maturity

questions.title: Fixed Income Bond Valuation_ Prices and Yields
questions.question:
The maturity effect is least likely to hold for a:

  1. zero-coupon bond.
  2. low-coupon, long-term bond trading at a discount.
  3. low-coupon, long-term bond trading at a premium.
questions.explanation: Solution Incorrect because the maturity effect will always hold for a zero-coupon bond. Correct. In some situations, the maturity effect may not hold for a low-coupon bond that is trading below par. Incorrect because the maturity effect will hold for a low-coupon bond that is trading above par. Fixed-Income Bond Valuation: Prices and Yields identify the relationships among a bond‚Äôs price, coupon rate, maturity, and yield-to-maturity
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Incorrect because the maturity effect will always hold for a zero-coupon bond.

  2. Correct. In some situations, the maturity effect may not hold for a low-coupon bond that is trading below par.

  3. Incorrect because the maturity effect will hold for a low-coupon bond that is trading above par.

Fixed-Income Bond Valuation: Prices and Yields

  • identify the relationships among a bond‚Äôs price, coupon rate, maturity, and yield-to-maturity
